natural problem: Find the largest value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $|5x-1|=x+3$.
natural solution: We can split the expression $|5x-1|=x+3$ into two separate cases. In the first case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=x+3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 4x&=4 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=1 \end{align}If we plug this value of $x$ back into the original equation in order to check our answer, we see that $|5(1)-1|=1+3$ or $4=4$.

Since this is true, we can accept $x=1$ as a valid solution. In the second case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=-(x+3) \\ 5x-1&=-x-3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 6x&=-2 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=-\frac13. \end{align}If we plug $-\frac13$ back into the initial equation, we get that $\left|5\left(-\frac13\right)-1\right|=-\frac13+3$, which simplifies to $\left|-\frac{8}{3}\right|=\frac{8}{3}$, or $\frac{8}{3}=\frac{8}{3}$.

Since this is also a true statement, we can accept $x=-\frac13$ as a valid solution as well. Since both $x=1$ and $x=-\frac13$ are possible values of $x$, the final answer is the larger of the two: $x=\boxed{1}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3"
shows  "x = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the largest value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $|5x-1|=x+3$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We can split the expression $|5x-1|=x+3$ into two separate cases. In the first case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=x+3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 4x&=4 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=1 \end{align}If we plug this value of $x$ back into the original equation in order to check our answer, we see that $|5(1)-1|=1+3$ or $4=4$.
 Since this is true, we can accept $x=1$ as a valid solution. In the second case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=-(x+3) \\ 5x-1&=-x-3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 6x&=-2 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=-\frac13. \end{align}If we plug $-\frac13$ back into the initial equation, we get that $\left|5\left(-\frac13\right)-1\right|=-\frac13+3$, which simplifies to $\left|-\frac{8}{3}\right|=\frac{8}{3}$, or $\frac{8}{3}=\frac{8}{3}$.
 Since this is also a true statement, we can accept $x=-\frac13$ as a valid solution as well. Since both $x=1$ and $x=-\frac13$ are possible values of $x$, the final answer is the larger of the two: $x=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3"
shows  "x = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that satisfies $|5x - 1| = x + 3$. The final answer is $1$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3"
shows  "GREATEST a. \<exists> x. abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3 = a"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the largest value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $|5x-1|=x+3$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We can split the expression $|5x-1|=x+3$ into two separate cases. In the first case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=x+3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 4x&=4 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=1 \end{align}If we plug this value of $x$ back into the original equation in order to check our answer, we see that $|5(1)-1|=1+3$ or $4=4$.
 Since this is true, we can accept $x=1$ as a valid solution. In the second case, \begin{align} 5x-1&=-(x+3) \\ 5x-1&=-x-3 \\\Rightarrow \qquad 6x&=-2 \\\Rightarrow \qquad x&=-\frac13. \end{align}If we plug $-\frac13$ back into the initial equation, we get that $\left|5\left(-\frac13\right)-1\right|=-\frac13+3$, which simplifies to $\left|-\frac{8}{3}\right|=\frac{8}{3}$, or $\frac{8}{3}=\frac{8}{3}$.
 Since this is also a true statement, we can accept $x=-\frac13$ as a valid solution as well. Since both $x=1$ and $x=-\frac13$ are possible values of $x$, the final answer is the larger of the two: $x=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3"
shows  "GREATEST a. \<exists> x. abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3 = a"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the largest value of $|5x - 1|$ when $|5x - 1| = x + 3$.

 *)

fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3"
shows  "GREATEST a. \<exists> x. abs (5 * x - 1) = x + 3 = 1"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
